title: Classic Commercials & Slogans
description: From catchy jingles to unforgettable taglines — how well do you remember America's most iconic ads?

questions.question: Which fast-food chain used the slogan 'Where's the beef?' in a famous 1984 commercial?
questions.explanation: Wendy's 'Where's the beef?' ad featured Clara Peller questioning the tiny burger patties of competitors. The phrase became a national catchphrase and was even used in the 1984 presidential campaign.

questions.question: Which cereal brand has long used the slogan 'They're Gr-r-reat!' with Tony the Tiger as its mascot?
questions.explanation: Tony the Tiger has been the mascot of Frosted Flakes (originally Sugar Frosted Flakes) since 1952. His enthusiastic 'They're Gr-r-reat!' is one of the longest-running slogans in advertising.

questions.question: Which soft drink brand ran the 1971 'Hilltop' commercial featuring young people singing 'I'd Like to Buy the World a Coke'?
questions.explanation: The Coca-Cola 'Hilltop' ad was filmed on a hill outside Rome, Italy, and is considered one of the greatest commercials ever made. The jingle was later released as a pop single.

questions.question: Which brand's commercials featured the slogan 'Plop, plop, fizz, fizz, oh what a relief it is'?
questions.explanation: Alka-Seltzer's catchy jingle debuted in 1976 and became one of the most memorable advertising tunes of the era. The campaign actually doubled sales by showing two tablets instead of one.

questions.question: Which battery brand's commercials feature a pink bunny that 'keeps going and going and going'?
questions.explanation: The Energizer Bunny debuted in 1989 as a parody of Duracell's battery commercials. The drumming bunny became so popular that 'keeps going and going' entered everyday language.

questions.question: Which brand used the jingle 'See the USA in your ___' in a famous 1950s ad campaign?
questions.explanation: Dinah Shore famously sang 'See the USA in Your Chevrolet' on her TV show, making it one of the most recognizable automotive jingles of the 1950s.

questions.question: Which cigarette brand advertised with the slogan 'I'd walk a mile for a ___'?
questions.explanation: Camel used the slogan 'I'd Walk a Mile for a Camel' starting in 1921, and it remained popular for decades. Before the 1971 TV ad ban, cigarette ads were among the most creative on television.

questions.question: Which fast-food restaurant used the slogan 'Have it your way' starting in the 1970s?
questions.explanation: Burger King's 'Have It Your Way' campaign launched in 1974, emphasizing customization as a contrast to McDonald's standardized approach. The catchy jingle became hugely popular.

questions.question: Which product's 1970s commercial featured the line 'Is it live, or is it Memorex?'
questions.explanation: Memorex's famous campaign featured Ella Fitzgerald shattering a glass with her voice, then asking if the recording could do the same. It demonstrated the quality of their blank cassette tapes.

questions.question: Which household cleaner brand featured a mascot with a bald head, single earring, and muscular build?
questions.explanation: Mr. Clean was introduced by Procter & Gamble in 1958. The muscular, bald mascot with an earring was one of the first animated characters in TV advertising and became an American icon.

questions.question: Which insurance company's commercials featured the slogan 'You're in good hands'?
questions.explanation: Allstate's 'You're in Good Hands' slogan has been used since 1950, making it one of the longest-running advertising slogans in history. It was inspired by an employee watching his daughter being cared for.

questions.question: Which 1984 Super Bowl commercial, directed by Ridley Scott, introduced a new personal computer to the world?
questions.explanation: Apple's iconic '1984' commercial introduced the Macintosh. It aired only once during the Super Bowl but is widely considered the greatest TV commercial of all time.

questions.question: Which brand's 1960s-70s commercials showed a Native American shedding a tear over littering and pollution?
questions.explanation: The 'Crying Indian' ad first aired on Earth Day 1971 for Keep America Beautiful. Actor Iron Eyes Cody became synonymous with the anti-pollution movement, and the ad ran for over a decade.

questions.question: Which children's cereal used the slogan 'Silly rabbit, Trix are for kids!'?
questions.explanation: The Trix Rabbit has been trying — and failing — to get a bowl of Trix cereal from kids since 1959. In rare promotional events, consumers voted to finally let the rabbit have some.

questions.question: Which razor brand's jingle proclaimed 'The best a man can get'?
questions.explanation: Gillette introduced 'The Best a Man Can Get' in 1989 during the Super Bowl. The slogan was used for nearly 30 years and became one of the most recognized taglines in advertising history.
